content.description: Furthest right route on the wall. Climb directly up slabs in the middle of a the bowl on the right side of the formation. Aim for the break in the rocks up high and pull the fractured overhang. Angle up to the right to the anchors.
content.protection: Small pro for some of the thin horizontal cracks on the slab. Some medium pieces to protect the roof pull. 2 bolt anchor up top.
content.location: Further right route on the wall, in the center of the bowl just past the portion of the wall with Negro Y Azul and Blue Sky.

content.description: Left side of the slab. Climb discontinuous crack past 2 large horizontal cracks to low angle slab exit.
content.protection: Single rack to 2 bolt anchor with rings
content.location: Crack to the left of Half measure.

content.description: The broken crack system on the right of the main wall. Finishes on right face.    Great trad practice route.
content.protection: Two (2) bolt anchor, one bolt high.   Small to medium pro.
content.location: Start at the base of the broken crack, up some Class 3 to top. 1 base belay anchor bolt without a hanger.   Walk off right, or Rap off.

content.protection: 2 bolts on the face, sm to med nuts   2 bolt anchor
content.location: On the South face of Pasta Pinnacle, which is up and to the right of the Spaghetti Wall. Route goes diagonal up the face to the left 'v' groove in the roof.    Rap down.

content.description: Easy slab past discontinuous left trending crack to single bolt. Continue to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Far right side of Pasta slab.

content.description: Pull the overhang to a run out slab.
content.protection: Two bolts on short face. Large #5/#6 cam at overhang. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Left bolted line on the block. Route finished up and over the the overhang. Rap down.

content.description: Slab climb with only a few areas that need some friction.
content.protection: Can either run straight sport or use a few pieces of pro. A medium piece before the first bolt and a piece of large pro in the wide horizontal crack for between bolt 1 and 2.   Two bolt anchor. Rap off, or walk off right class 3-4.

content.description: Consistent route. A few slab moves is all it is. Most of the de-laminating flakes of granite have been knocked off this route.
content.protection: Sport or use one large cam in the horizontal crack.   Two bolt anchor. Rap or walk off right.

content.description: Climb the crack and slabs immediately to the right of Blue Sky. Pull a fractured overhang and hook left to the shared anchors with Blue Sky.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts will protect the crack lower down. A larger piece will protect the crux. Two bolt anchor on top.
content.location: In the slabby bowl to the right of Blue Sky. 6th route on the wall from the left.

content.description: Crux is at the first bolt with thin face climbing. The small roof has many features to use to pull yourself over.
content.protection: 2 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. A large cam (BD #4 or #5) can be used to protect the small roof. The farther right you protect the roof, the smaller the cam needed. I used a BD #1 on the right side.
content.location: 5th route to the right on Spaghetti wall, shares the same slab and to the right of Negro y Azul.

content.description:
If someone else has climbed this, obviously let me know.   I saw this crack from above and it's hard to see from anywhere below at the trail or otherwise. We were not sure about it until we hiked up to it. On closer inspection it was much easier then what it looked from afar.    Called it Alfabeto - cause its as basic as the alphabet and Aaron was thinking about food as always... 

  Good intro trad crack.
content.protection: medium to large gear. Gear anchors. down climb right
content.location: Located on the west end of the Pasta Slab, near what looks like sliced bread boulders. It is a short crack on the South face. Start left traverse right. Traverse follows the sloping grade to the vertical crack.

content.description: New trails in the Preserve see hikers, horseback riders, and mountain bikers. Climbers are not as prevalent.Chunky granite and full sun.
